FUJI Develops System to Prevent Accidents Caused by Leaving Vehicles; Tests on Own Vehicles | Central Japan Economic Newspaper: Economic Information for Aichi, Gifu, Mie, and Shizuoka
FUJI (head office in Chiryu), which manufactures and sells robots for installing electronic components and machine tools, has started developing a system to prevent children from being left in cars.
The system involves installing motion sensors in the car that detect when people are moving, and then sending notifications to their phones or chats.
The company is now testing the technology on its own shuttle buses.
Protecting children from the pain of being left behind.

Currently, they are conducting a proof-of-concept experiment with two shuttle vehicles for their own after-school English conversation program for children, teracoya THANK, which operates in Chiryu City.
Sensors that detect human movement from the temperature difference between the person and their surroundings are installed in three locations on the ceiling of the car.
If the engine is turned off and the door is locked, and after a certain amount of time, the car detects movement, it will automatically send a warning notification.
By coordinating the engine and door status and information, it can prevent false detection as much as possible.
The warning notification is sent via the cloud.
You can call the number you registered in advance or display it on the chat of your computer or smartphone.
You can register multiple addresses and they take care to avoid mistakes like forgetting to send.
The proof-of-concept experiment will continue until the end of February.
"During the experiment, we also saw issues with the system's peripheral," said Kamiya Ichikazu, the head of the second section of the innovation promotion department.
For example, they were able to pick up on various challenges related to school buses, such as creating an environment that allows drivers to concentrate on driving.
You must spread the solution."
The development of the anti-abandonment system was triggered by a series of abandoned bus accidents across the country.
From employees with young children, I have received suggestions on what can be done to ensure the safety of children.
They decided to develop the IoT (Internet of Things) and sensor-based information management, which they had accumulated through their business related to FA (Factory Automation) related businesses.
FUJI's anti-theft system is easy to use.
Sensors can be installed by just pinning them to the ceiling.
Since it can be easily retrofitted to the shuttle bus, it makes it easier to introduce and aims to promote its widespread use.
In the future, they will be looking to collaborate with kindergartens and nurseries, as well as considering productization.

Echizen Town is making a handbook for foreign residents and distributing it to those who want it.

Last year, when he published a "funeral handbook" that covered all the necessary procedures and forms for writing a will, and also included a list of heirs and family trees, he found that many people came to him to get their own wills written.

In various parts of the prefecture, there are also classes on how to write an obituary and how to organize your affairs before you die, and it seems that "end-of-life activities" have become a fixture in the lives of the prefecture's citizens.
Echizen's ending note is 35 pages.

Chapter 5 begins with a review of your life history, and then you write down your current health status, financial situation, wishes for future care, end-of-life medical wishes, and preferences for funeral and burial.
There are also sections for things you want to do in the rest of your life and for leaving messages for people you care about.
It’s tempting to write 35 pages but you don’t need to bury every page.
What do you want to be remembered for, by your family and those around you?
The point is to make it clear what the purpose is.
There are many different notebooks available at bookstores and such that are tailored to your needs, and it's a good idea to start writing from the beginning.
He said that the term "end of life" was coined in 2009, and that it was used in conjunction with job hunting.
Two years later, the Great East Japan Earthquake occurred in 2011.
Many people have come to realize the reality that death can come suddenly, and there are more people who are preparing for their own end-of-life care.
It's been 10 years since then.
The worldwide coronavirus pandemic is still not over.
With the Russian invasion of Ukraine and other factors, prices have risen and electricity bills have skyrocketed this winter.
On the other hand, wages have not gone up as much as prices have gone up, and many people are struggling.
On the other hand, the cost of funerals, care, and burial management, which could be shared by relatives, is now rare in a time when only children are not uncommon.
Also, life expectancy has increased significantly in the past, but the dilemma is that the risk of dementia and care needs increases as we get older.
It is important to remember that the background to the fact that end-of-life care is becoming more permanent is the rise in social anxiety.
Either way, no one wants to burden their partner or children with excessive debt.
"Ending on your own terms" is a popular keyphrase for Ending Notes, but it's a bit like saying "I'm not going to die, I'm going to kill myself" - it's a bit too much of a cop-out.
I hope you don’t keep your wishes and desires to yourself, but instead consult your family and prepare for them calmly.

(4) The administration treats citizens living outside its jurisdiction as "outsiders" and gives them the cold shoulder.
(5) Depression and other mental illnesses are medicated and treated as “accidents” even if they commit suicide.
(6) “Duty of care” is forgotten in high-risk suicide areas and commercialism is rampant.

Introducing the pioneers of plant research, including Hayachine Mountain collection materials, at the City General Cultural Property Center Exhibition [Hanamaki] | Iwanichi Online Iwate Nippo

An exhibition titled "People who introduced the flowers of Hayachine - A brief history of Hayachine plant research" which features the pioneers who laid the foundation for the plant research of Hayachine, which is known as a treasure trove of alpine plants, is being held at the City General Cultural Property Center in Ohasama, Hanamaki City until the 12th.

The exhibition features 124 items, including valuable specimens collected by previous researchers, and introduces the footprints of previous researchers involved in the study of plants in Mount Hayachine.

The study of plants on Mt. Hayachine began with the Russian botanist Karl Ivanovich Maximowicz (1827-1891), who came to Japan in the late Edo period, and Sugawa Chonosuke (1842-1925), who collected plants under Maximowicz's guidance.
Unable to freely walk around the country as a foreigner, Maximo Wichmann asked Suzuki to collect data and continued his research for three years, based in Yokohama and Nagasaki.

After returning to Japan, Sugawara continued to support Maximo's research, which led to the discovery of Primula macrocarpa, Sanguisorba obtusa, and Aruncus dioicus, which are endemic to Mount Hayachine.

Later, modern botanist Makino Tomitaro (1862-1957) published "Draba japonica" and "Bistorta hayachinensis" in 1903 (Meiji 36) based on the collections of local researchers, and "Arenaria katoana" in 1905 (Meiji 38) after he climbed Mt.
From the exhibit materials, it is clear that many researchers have identified valuable alpine plants.

Also, the author introduces the work of Suginuma Masanosuke (1874-1948), who was a botanist and accompanied the survey of natural monuments in 1927 (Showa 2), and Tamakawa Shichiro (1914-1988), who worked as a museum curator at the Oohakamayama Museum and also participated in the publication of "The Plants of Mt.

"There is a lot of research and human connections behind the names of each plant on Mount Hayachine," said Yoshida, a researcher at the center. "We can see the connections between researchers from different regions who are spreading their research across the country."

The exhibition is divided into four chapters, with the first chapter focusing on the beliefs and history of Mt. Fuji, and the second chapter using the research of Heinrich Edmund Naumann (1854-1927), a German geologist who laid the foundation for Japanese geology, to describe the characteristics of Mt. Fuji from a geological perspective.

Rescue efforts to pull survivors from collapsed buildings and other debris in the bitter cold have become more difficult as time passes.
In the affected areas, the search for survivors is continuing.
The United Nations said on Tuesday that it had delivered aid across the Turkish border into the northwestern Syrian province of Idlib for the first time since the earthquake struck six days ago.
Idlib province was the last bastion of anti-regime fighters in Syria's civil war, and there were concerns that it would fall without international support.
In both countries, rescue operations are continuing, but they are struggling to use heavy machinery.
Many are believed to be buried under the rubble and the death toll is likely to rise.
Turkish authorities say they have confirmed 17,674 deaths in Turkey.
The death toll in Turkey now stands at more than 17,000, surpassing the 1999 earthquake in northwestern Turkey that killed more than 17,000.

Amami Airport: Second Carbon Neutral Promotion Council Meeting | Society & Economy | Nankai Daily
Promotion Council for Decarbonization of Amami Airport Meets to Discuss the Matter = On the 9th, Kasari Town, Amami City

The "Amami Airport Decarbonization Promotion Council" (Chairman: Takahashi, head of the construction section of the Amami Oshima Subprefectural Office, 13 members) which is made up of the prefecture and airlines that use the airport, held its second meeting at the airport on the 9th.
All members, including online members, attended.
The exchange of opinions was focused on setting the goal of decarbonization and introducing renewable energy, with solar power as the main focus.

The Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism has set a total goal of reducing greenhouse gas emissions at each airport by 46% (compared to 2013) by 2050, with the aim of achieving "carbon neutrality" by that date.
In response, the council held its first meeting in November last year, and is aiming to establish a plan ahead of other airports on the other six islands in the prefecture.
The second meeting, as with the first, was closed to the public except for the opening.
After the meeting, Atō, who responded to the press, said that the group confirmed the amount of greenhouse gas emissions at the airport.
The ministry said it has been holding talks along the lines of the guidelines to set targets and introduce renewable energy.
According to the distribution material, the benchmark for the 13th year's CO2 emissions from airport facilities and vehicles was 1476 tons (excluding aircraft).
Of these, the airport terminal building and seven other facilities account for about 90% of the emissions, with 84 tons of airport lights and 71 tons of airport vehicles following.
The council will discuss reducing the emissions of these facilities and vehicles.
"We are at a crossroads," said Ando. "The direction of the committee is in agreement, and I would like to firmly compile the interim report."
In the future, the third meeting will hear the interim report and the fourth meeting will hear the final report, and then the plan will be formulated.
Establishing "Opposite Real Estate" Okinagawa Branch Office to bring people to the island. People who want to rent a house are recruited. | Society & Economy | Minami-Kyushu Nippo
Opening event to deepen understanding of "reverse real estate" through talk sessions, etc. = August 8, famous town

The Okinoerabu Branch Office of the "Sakasama Real Estate" service, which matches landlords with people who want to rent out their empty houses or shops, held its opening event on the 8th at the popular community space "entaku" in the popular town of Chinacho.
The operating company will explain the service overview in a talk session.

"If we can do this on Okinoerabu Island, we can bring people to the island and create a movement and flow," said Tsukinoba Okubo, the representative director of the branch office that runs the operation (in Rishiri, Hokkaido).

Saskatchewan real estate works in reverse of normal real estate, where they post information about people looking to rent and then contact landlords and if they agree they can sign the contract themselves.
As a proof of concept experiment to uncover potential vacant homes and build relationships through vacant homes, On-Co Co., Ltd. (headquarters Mie Prefecture) operates and began service in June 2020.
The opening of the branch office is the seventh in Kyushu.
It is the first time in the country for an island.
The event was attended by about 20 people, including staff from On-Co and Tsukino-ba, the town halls of Wakasa and Shimane, and local residents.

Okubo, the representative director, explained the process of opening the branch office, saying, "As the movement to bring people from outside the island is becoming more active, I thought that if we could utilize empty houses and empty stores, the town and the island would become more lively."
"I want to help people who have properties on the island or people who want to do something, connect them and help them to make progress with their projects, one by one," he said.
On-Co's Mizutani Gakushi representative said, "We need to talk to the locals about how they want to use each vacant house, who they want to come and live there, and what criteria they want to use."
"The more people connect with each other, the more information will be gathered," he said, calling for participation in discussions and cooperation in providing information.

I guess Seongpyeong looks like a hunk (laugh) Persona 5 is already beautiful, so the freshness is not that great... If you think that way, then the third option is more convenient.
As a game, I found 5 easier to play than 3.
Persona 3 is mostly blue, but the backgrounds are dark and hard to see.
5 is mainly bright colors like red and yellow, so it's easy to see even if it's covered by the background.
With the assist feature, I think even those who are not good at gaming can enjoy it.
I think the challenge feature makes it a more challenging game for those who are more experienced with the game.
The triple pack has the soundtrack, and it’s a proper 4 disc set, so if you like the Persona music I’d recommend this one.

I used the SIM free iPhone 7s.

At first setup, I didn't know what to do after arriving in Korea and pointing my SIM, so I asked a woman at the SK counter at Gimpo airport (turn data roaming ON from settings > mobile communication > communication options) and it worked out fine.
The theory attached to the product didn't seem to have much to do with it...?
I've been having trouble with 3G reception in the Gimpo airport area, where the signal is pretty bad.
When I went out, it became 4G.
I remember sometimes it got really slow in the evening and night, but I think it was capped at like a few hundred MB a day.
it's better than i thought.

I had been using a Softbank Z4 for 2 years, had it unlocked and was using it on Ymobile, but it was getting old and I was looking to buy a used Xperia, but I found this phone and bought it, which is a new phone that can be used on any carrier.
I was worried that I wouldn't be able to use it because I was using Mobile Suica, but it was no problem at all.
Size, weight, silver, bought it, I think it's an iPhone6?

I don't play games so I don't know how fast it is, but I have the impression it's a bit faster than Z4.  I read a review that said the fingerprint recognition was slow, but I have the impression it takes a bit of time to recognize it, so I use the face recognition.
I thought it was like an iPhone and it was awesome. I also upgraded to Android Ver9 and I was able to make a satisfying purchase.

Things I noticed  It could be smaller  No strap hole  *It is compatible with cases with a strap hole  I have not tested the water resistance  It is a bit heavy  I have not used it much but I am satisfied  I recommend it
